annotation.TEXT: This room in particular demonstrates a gimmick that I've never really been fond of. The destructible blocks are a decent concept on their own, but the constant shifting of the room only amounts to more waiting while trying to line up your shots for them (if you're not careful with this, you can easily hit a block you weren't supposed to and effectively end up with no way to progress).

So then, for reference on what's next: No, I won't be doing Rockman 2 Final Mix. qzecwx already covered that train wreck well enough, and I pretty much have nothing else to add on to what he stated about it. That, and I'd rather not play a MM2 hack that has more problems than the original game.

The bosses of these stages aren't much better, to be honest. "Big Pets" is now weak to the Super Arrow, which wouldn't be so bad if not for the fact that he launches out enemies at a much faster rate. Unless you hit him at point blank range, there's a very strong chance that your Super Arrow will be destroyed by one of the falling enemies before it can reach him.

Overall though, it's still a good addition to the ever-growing list of hacks for these games. At least, in terms of the ones that actually make extensive changes (rather than adjusting the tiles/layouts and calling it a day).

So then, instead I'll be taking on Mega Man: Revenge of the Fallen next. I know Darkflamewolf (the creator of said game) had messaged me about this a while back, and I think it's long over-due for a playthrough on my channel by now.

No quick transition with a weird sound clip this time, sadly. I was originally going to, but you immediately fight Wily after finishing up all the re-fights in this hack. The transition back to the teleporter room after my usual running gag would have looked a bit strange if I had went with it.
Huh...I'm getting flashbacks to Super Mega Man 3 now. Thankfully, this was a far better game by comparison.
The Apache Joes don't help much either. If one of them gets too close, they'll practically stick to you until you destroy them.

Wily himself isn't too difficult, at least in terms of his overall patterns. The main problem is that his damage output is way too high for its own good. It's not too apparent in his first phase, but his second phase can basically kill you in roughly 4 hits or so.

Granted, this hack still isn't without a few flaws though. Some of the weapons could still use some fine tuning, and the castle stages are still nowhere near as fun as some of the Robot Master levels.

I'm honestly not too big on the original Mega Man 5, but for what it's worth, RM5 Install Metal is pretty fun. There's some solid work here that makes this hack stand out a bit, especially when it comes to the music. Even a few of the minor changes (such as retaining your charge after being hit) make this hack a worthwhile experience.

So then, how does everyone here feel about mazes? Personally, I don't mind them if they're done right. This one however, is one of "those" mazes: the type that loop if you go the wrong way. Although the maze itself is pretty short, it can still amount to a lot of trial and error the first time through (especially if you accidentally take one of the paths that send you back to the beginning).

For me, the Wily Castle in this hack is in the same boat as the Dark Man stages: It's not exactly fun, if mainly due to a few trouble spots and quirks with the levels. Thankfully, these stages are pretty short...although the second one can be a bit subjective even in those regards (you'll see what I mean).

As a forewarning however: Revenge of the Fallen is a pretty long game. We're talking like 15 to 18 segments worth of content here. It'll probably take me a while to complete it, but it's definitely something I've been wanting to get around to. Until then, I'd suggest playing this hack if you haven't already (and don't play Final Mix, unless you somehow felt that your rom hacks didn't contain nearly enough Pepsi for some reason).
